node.title: Meet the nearby black holes that are set to collide and create a 'monster'
node.alt: Close-up and wide views of the nearest pair of supermassive black holes.
node.description: Astronomers have discovered a pair of supermassive black holes that are the closest to Earth ever observed â€“ and they're on a collision course with each other.
node.content:
["Astronomers have discovered a pair of supermassive black holes that are the closest to Earth ever observed \u2013 and they're on a collision course with each other.", "Located some 89 million light-years away\u00a0(for context, one light-year is equivalent to about 9.47 trillion kilometres) in the galaxy NGC 7727,\u00a0they're believed to be about 154 million time and 6.3 million times bigger than the\u00a0Sun.", "So what do we know about the discovery? And what does it mean for us Earthlings?", "
They're closer to us (and each other) than we thought
", "Using the European Southern Observatory\u2019s Very Large Telescope (they really took naming duties in their own creative direction), researchers were able to make two key discoveries.", "First and foremost, they're a lot closer to Earth than anything we've seen before.\u00a0", "Sure, you probably won't have to cancel your weekend plans given they're still 89 million light-years away, but when you consider the previous record was 470 million light-years, the discovery is significant.", "Second, in addition to being closer to us than previously thought, they're also pretty chummy with one another.", "With just 1,600 light-years between them, the pair in NGC 7727 beat the record for the smallest separation between two supermassive black holes.", "And by examining how the gravitational pull of the black holes influences\u00a0the motion of the stars around them, astronomers have\u00a0even able to determine exactly how big they are.", "The bigger black hole, located right at the core of NGC 7727, has a mass almost 154 million times that of the Sun, while its companion is 6.3 million solar masses.", "\"It is the first time we find two supermassive black holes that are this close to each other,\" says Karina Voggel, an astronomer at the Strasbourg Observatory in France and lead author of the study.", "\"[That's] less than half the separation of the previous record holder.\"", "
OK, so what does that actually mean?
", "Supermassive black holes lurk at the centre of massive galaxies. When two such galaxies merge, the black holes end up on a collision course.", "According to the researchers, the small separation between these ones means they'll \"merge into one monster black hole\".", "", "
Supermassive black holes lurk at the centre of massive galaxies.(Supplied: European Space Agency)
", "When that occurs, gravitational waves are released, what the European Space Agency calls\u00a0\"fluctuations in the fabric of space-time\".", "\"Simulations predict that these mergers \u2026\u00a0emit both gravitational waves and radiation \u2014\u00a0the latter originating in the hot, interstellar gas of the two colliding galaxies stirred by the black holes pair when they fall towards one another,\" it noted.", "But, with an estimated 250 million years until they hit, you probably won't need to worry about that.", "
Could there be more out there?
", "That's what scientists reckon.", "The merging of black holes like these could explain how the most massive black holes in the universe come to be.", "While astronomers had suspected the galaxy hosted the two black holes, they hadn't been able to confirm their presence until now.", "That's because they don't usually see \"large amounts of high-energy radiation coming from their immediate surroundings\", which would otherwise give them away.", "\"Our finding implies that there might be many more of these relics of galaxy mergers out there and they may contain many hidden massive black holes that still wait to be found,\"\u00a0Dr Voggel says.", "\"It could increase the total number of supermassive black holes known in the local universe by 30 per cent.\""]
